Graphical abstract Metallocene catalysts are pivotal in enabling the high-temperature solution polymerization of ethylene/1-octene to produce polyolefin elastomers. Among these, bridged metallocene catalysts are particularly valuable commercially owing to their exceptional thermal stability and high catalytic activity. However, their diverse and complex structural characteristics pose major challenges in the precise and controllable design and synthesis of catalysts that simultaneously exhibit high activity, superior copolymerization performance, and the ability to produce high-molecular-weight polymers. Herein, the quantitative structure–activity relationships (QSARs) of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts for ethylene/1-octene copolymerization were investigated through a combined experimental and density functional theory approach. In contrast to most studies that focus solely on the catalyst structure, our findings emphasize the importance of analyzing catalyst performance based on the transition state species formed during the reaction. Specifically, the ∠CCp–M−CFlu and the ∠M–Cα–Hα of ethylene π-complexes in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2M(iBu)]+ were identified as important influencing factor of catalytic activity. Additionally, the M–Cα bond length in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)+…C2H4] ‡ was found to influence copolymerization performance, while the Cα–M−C1−C2 twist angle in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC2H4(iBu)+…C2H4]‡ directly affected the molecular weight of the polymerization product. These QSARs were further validated through machine learning and experimental verification. Based on these insights, a novel high-performance catalyst was designed and synthesized. Finally, a universally applicable digital catalyst model with high-throughput screening capabilities was developed, leveraging the obtained QSARs. Keywords Polyolefin elastomer Metallocene catalysts Machine learning in catalysis Catalyst digital model High-throughput screening Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Driven by the rapid growth of the photovoltaic industry, polyolefin elastomer (POE), synthesized via high-temperature solution polymerization of ethylene/1-octene, has garnered remarkable attention owing to its exceptional performance as a photovoltaic film [1]. The outstanding properties of POE stem from its unique microstructure—a highly branched architecture with long-chain branches—precisely engineered using metallocene catalysts [2,3]. Furthermore, to achieve optimal elastomeric properties (combining rubber elasticity at room temperature and resin plasticity at high temperature), both the 1-octene insertion rate and the polymer molecular weight must satisfy specific thresholds [4,5]. In industrial practice, while polymerization conditions could regulate product properties, metallocene catalysts with high copolymerization performance were crucial to reduce both expensive comonomer consumption and process control complexity. Specifically, metallocene catalysts exhibiting high thermal stability, polymerization activity, and copolymerization efficiency are critical for POE production [5]. Owing to their extended conjugated systems, molecular stability, and structural tunability via substituent modulation, bridged metallocene catalysts have been extensively studied for ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization at elevated temperatures [6–9]. Among them, the metallocene complex (R1)2X(R2Cp)(R3Flu)MCl2 (Scheme 1 ) has attracted special interest, as its bulky fluorenyl ligands suppress β-H elimination, enabling the synthesis of high-molecular-weight polyolefins—a key metric for POE performance [7,10]. To enhance catalyst performance in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization, extensive efforts have focused on the design and fine-tuning of these catalysts [9,11,12]. Modifications to the bridging groups in bridged metallocene catalysts (R1 in Scheme 1) have shown that electron-donating substituents enhance catalytic activity of the catalysts in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization and increase polymer molecular weight [13,14]. For cyclopentadienyl modifications (R2 in Scheme 1), 3-bit/β-bit substitutions modulate catalyst activity but tend to reduce polymer molecular weight [7]. Conversely, 2,7-bit substitutions on the fluorenyl group (R3 in Scheme 1) can increase polymer molecular weight [15], though this often comes at the cost of reduced catalytic activity of the metallocene catalysts owing to increased steric hindrance of the metallocene molecule [16]. Additionally, researchers have investigated metallocene properties from a geometric structural perspective. It is widely accepted that the dihedral angle β formed by two cyclopentadienyl rings of metallocene (Scheme 1) plays a critical role in determining metallocene properties [17–20]. Specifically, a small β angle (and thus a large α, the angle between the lines connecting the metal center atom to the centers of the two cyclopentadienyl rings) correlates with high catalytic activity [20]. However, copolymerization performance exhibits the opposite trend [20]; that is, a large β angle (resulting in a small α) enhances copolymerization performance of the metallocene catalysts in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization. These findings highlight the difficulty in simultaneously achieving high activity, high polymer molecular weight, and superior copolymerization performance in metallocenes—a key limitation that has hindered the precise design of these catalysts. Moreover, prior studies have primarily addressed the structure–activity relationship between catalyst modifications and only one or two factors (e.g., catalytic activity, copolymerization performance, or polymer molecular weight). A comprehensive quantitative structure–activity relationship (QSAR) study encompassing all three key factors—polymerization activity, 1-octene insertion rate, and polymer molecular weight—may unlock a new pathway for metallocene catalyst design. Building on these insights, a series of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts were designed, synthesized, and structurally optimized. To establish a detailed and comprehensive structure–activity relationship, the regulatory mechanisms of these catalysts were investigated through mechanistic studies. Ethylene/1-octene polymerization experiments, through the characterization of polymer products, and mechanistic analyses using density functional theory (DFT) enabled a systematic investigation of the QSARs of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts, including their catalytic performance and the microstructure of the resulting polymers. Additionally, machine learning was integrated with experimental research to validate key factors influencing catalytic activity and polymer microstructure. A universally applicable digital catalyst model with high-throughput screening capabilities was further developed, enabling the design of a novel catalyst that concurrently achieves high activity, high polymer molecular weight, and superior copolymerization performance. 2 Methods 2.1 Experimental methods The synthesis, characterization, and structural confirmation of metallocene catalysts are detailed in the Supporting Information (Section 1: parts Ⅰ). Ethylene/1-octene copolymerization was performed using a high-pressure polymerization reactor, with the procedure outlined in the Supporting Information (Section 1: parts Ⅱ). To ensure data reliability, the results presented in this paper were averaged from three independent polymerization experiments. The resulting polymers were characterized via high-temperature gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and high-temperature 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) (Supporting Information Section 1: parts Ⅲ). 2.2 Computational methods Quantum chemical calculations were conducted using DFT at the B3LYP level within the Gaussian 16 software to optimize the geometries of all intermediates and transition states of the metallocenes [21]. The def2-QZVPD basis set was employed for the central metal atoms in the metallocene catalysts, while the 6-31G* basis set was applied to all other atoms in the system [22,23]. As the polymerization reaction was conducted in n-hexane, solvation effects were incorporated using the integral equation formalism polarizable continuum model [24]. For fully optimized structures, all Hessian matrix calculations were required to yield real vibrational frequencies for each normal mode, thereby ensuring that the geometries corresponded to local minima. For each transition state, the presence of a single imaginary frequency corresponding to the correct normal mode was verified. Additionally, the single-point energies of all catalysts were computed at the same theoretical level. The artificial neural network (ANN) architecture employed in this study was designed based on the methodology described in reference [25]. (Further details are provided in the Supporting Information). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 QSARs study from the perspective of catalyst in isolation As illustrated in Scheme 2 , a C 1-symmetric silicon-bridged metallocene was selected as the primary framework of bridged metallocene catalysts and modified based on four key aspects: bridging atom substituents, cyclopentadienyl substituents, fluorenyl substituents, and metal center atoms. Consequently, 11 novel metallocene catalysts were designed and synthesized. Under optimized polymerization conditions (see Supporting Information Section 2 for details), the catalytic performance of all metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization was evaluated, with the results summarized in Table 1 . As outlined in the introduction, catalyst performance was assessed based on three key metrics: polymerization activity, product molecular weight, and 1-octene insertion rate. Analysis of Table 1 revealed that a series of metallocene catalysts with varying catalytic performances in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization were successfully synthesized through targeted structural modifications. Notably, metallocene catalysts sharing the same core structure but differing in bridging atom, cyclopentadienyl, fluorenyl substituents, or metal center atoms exhibited profound differences in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization activity, product molecular weight, and 1-octene insertion rate. To systematically evaluate the effects of structural modifications on catalytic performance, we conducted a detailed comparative analysis of metallocene catalysts with the same core structure but differing in specific substituents. This included comparisons of bridging atom substituents (M1 vs. M2, M5 vs. M3, M9 vs. M6, and M7 vs. M10), cyclopentadienyl substituents (M1 vs. M5, M2 vs. M3, and M10 vs. M11), fluorenyl substituents (M1 vs. M9, M2 vs. M6, and M7 vs. M8), and metal center atoms (M1 vs. M7, M2 vs. M10, M3 vs. M11, and M9 vs. M8), as illustrated in Scheme 2. Through systematic analysis of the polymerization data presented in Table 1, several key trends emerged. First, the introduction of electron-donating groups to the cyclopentadienyl or fluorenyl substituents significantly enhanced the polymerization activity of the catalysts, whereas replacing the central metal from Zr to Hf consistently resulted in reduced activity. This trend was corroborated across multiple comparative sets. For instance, catalysts featuring electron-donating modifications on either cyclopentadienyl or fluorenyl ligands exhibited higher activity, while those with Hf as the central metal generally showed lower activity compared to their Zr analogues. Second, the incorporation of electron-donating groups into the cyclopentadienyl substituents led to a decrease in the molecular weight of the polymer products. This trend was further supported in studies on fluorenyl substituent modification, where the introduction of electron-donating groups also generally reduced molecular weight, except in certain Hf-based catalysts (e.g., M7 vs M8), where the metal center exerted a counteracting effect. Lastly, electron-donating modifications on the fluorenyl substituents improved copolymerization performance, as evidenced by a systematic increase in the 1-octene insertion rate. In studies on bridging atom substitution, changing the bridge from Me to Ph generally increased the insertion rate, although the trend was reversed in the M7 vs M10 pair due to the presence of Hf. Furthermore, investigations into metal center modulation revealed that the enhancement in copolymerization performance resulting from fluorenyl modification remained consistent across different metal centers, although the extent of improvement depended on the type of bridging atom. In summary, this study led to the following conclusions: (1) Polymerization activity was notably enhanced by introducing electron-donating groups to the cyclopentadienyl or fluorenyl substituents, whereas replacing the central metal from Zr to Hf resulted in decreased activity. (2) The molecular weight of the polymer products decreased upon the introduction of electron-donating groups to the cyclopentadienyl substituents. (3) Copolymerization performance, indicated by 1-octene insertion rates, improved with electron-donating group substitution on the fluorenyl substituents. However, other potentially important correlations—including the effects of bridging atom substitution on catalyst properties, cyclopentadienyl modification on 1-octene insertion rates, fluorenyl modification on product molecular weights, and metal center atom variation on both molecular weights and insertion rates—remained unclear and did not follow predictable patterns. Instead, complex interactions among multiple modification factors were observed, exhibiting either synergistic or antagonistic effects of modification of substituents or metal center atoms. Extensive studies on C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts have led to the establishment of several general principles governing their structure–activity relationships [20,26]. As illustrated in Scheme 1, the distance (D) from the central metal atom to the line connecting the two cyclopentadienyl centers has been identified as a key factor influencing catalytic activity, while the angle (α) between the vectors from the metal center to each cyclopentadienyl center is found to influence 1-octene insertion [20]. Building upon these established principles, we analyzed the QSARs of our synthesized catalysts in light of existing theories on C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene structure–activity relationships. However, our findings diverged from these established trends. The observed discrepancy may be attributed to variations in experimental conditions or differences in the polymer samples. To more accurately investigate the structure–activity relationships of the catalysts, we shifted our focus to the mechanistic study of the ethylene/1-octene copolymerization process catalyzed by metallocenes. Specifically, we performed structural optimization for all metallocene catalysts under both vacuum and solvent conditions, with the resulting structural parameters summarized in Table S5. A comprehensive analysis of the catalytic performance data in Table 1 revealed that our results did not align with previously reported QSAR principles, regardless of the computational environment, including vacuum or solvent conditions. For instance, although M2 exhibited a larger D value than M1, its catalytic activity was considerably lower. Similarly, despite M2 having a larger α angle than M7, it demonstrated a reduced 1-octene insertion rate. Our analysis clearly demonstrates that defining reliable QSARs for C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization is challenging when considering structural modifications or geometric parameters in isolation. This suggests that QSAR analysis should focus on the structure of the transition state formed during the reaction, rather than on the standalone catalyst structure. Accordingly, we performed a comprehensive analysis of the reaction pathway using DFT calculations and integrated these results with experimental data to identify the key factors influencing polymerization activity of metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization, polymer molecular weight, and 1-octene insertion rates. This approach enabled us to establish accurate QSARs for C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization, providing a foundation for the development of an intelligent model correlating catalyst structure with its performance. 3.2 QSARs study from the perspective of catalyst in reaction process 3.2.1 Establishment of polymer model To establish a reliable polymer model, we conducted a comprehensive high-temperature 13C NMR analysis of all polymerization products. This analysis yielded the ternary sequence distribution, which reflects the microstructure of the polymer (Table 1). The results revealed that the EEE fragment was the dominant component across all polymers, followed by the EEO fragment. Other fragment types were present in minimal quantities. Based on these findings, we selected the EEE repeating unit as the foundation for the initial polymer model. For the ethylene/1-octene copolymerization process, we implemented the widely accepted coordination polymerization mechanism of metallocene-catalyzed olefin polymerization [6,7,27]. Fig. 1 illustrates the polymerization reaction process using the EEE fragment model: (1) First ethylene insertion: The metallocene catalyst and cocatalyst Al(iBu)3 form an alkylated metallocene active center [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2M(iBu)]+ (Species 1). Subsequent coordination between the ethylene monomer and the vacancy of the metal active center generates ethylene π-complexes [Cp(R1)Ind(R2) 2Si(R) 2M(iBu)] + (Species 2). Following coordination, partial electron transfer from the carbon–carbon double bond in olefin creates a four-membered ring transition state [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2M(iBu)…C2H4]‡ (Species 3). Ethylene then inserts into the chain connected to the active metal–organic group, completing the first polymerization step to form [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R) 2MC2H4(iBu)] + (Species 4). (2) Second ethylene insertion: The active center of the polymer chain coordinates with a new ethylene molecule, forming a new π-complex (ethylene π-complexes of [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC2H4(iBu)]+, Species 5). Subsequent electron transfer generates another four-membered transition state Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC2H4(iBu)+…C2H4]‡ (Species 6), followed by ethylene insertion to form [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)]+ (Species 7). (3) Third ethylene insertion: The third ethylene insertion forms another π-complex (ethylene π-complexes of [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)]+, Species 8) and a four-membered ring transition state [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)+…C2H4]‡ (Species 9). (4) β-H elimination: Following three consecutive ethylene insertions forming the EEE sequence, β-hydrogen elimination terminates chain growth. We employed DFT to calculate the complete ethylene/1-octene copolymerization process catalyzed by metallocene catalysts (Fig. 1), with energy barriers summarized in Table 2 . The transition state energy barrier of the initial ethylene insertion (ΔG 1) plays a key role in determining chain growth initiation [28,29]. Thermodynamically and kinetically, low energy barriers facilitate rapid transformation of ethylene monomers into active chain growth intermediates, promoting efficient polymerization initiation and progression [28,29]. Consequently, low barriers typically correspond to high polymerization reactivity. Our calculations (Table 2) and experimental data (Table 1) demonstrate consistent correlation between low ΔG 1 values and high polymerization activity, validating our EEE fragment–based model for exploring catalyst reactivity. Regarding polymer molecular weight, energy barrier for the β-H elimination influences chain termination during growth [30,31]. The energy difference between the insertion transition state and the β-H elimination transition state (denoted as ΔG 3 − ΔGβ -H) reflects the kinetic competition between chain propagation and termination. A larger value indicates a higher barrier for β-H elimination relative to monomer insertion, thereby favoring the formation of high-molecular-weight polymers. Our data (Tables 1 and 2) consistently show that catalysts with high |ΔG 3 − ΔGβ -H| values produce high-molecular-weight polymers, confirming the validity of the EEE fragment model for molecular weight analysis. We further investigated the rationale for using EEE versus EEO fragments as model bases for copolymerization properties. For instance, using the M2 catalyst, EEO fragment modeling (with third 1-octene insertion) requires overcoming a 15.702 Kcal/mol barrier (ΔG 3), compared to 18.209 Kcal/mol for EEE fragment modeling (third ethylene insertion, Table 2). While simulations suggest a high EEO content, experimental results show great EEE abundance (Table 1), supporting the use of EEE fragment modeling for copolymerization mechanism studies. In conclusion, our selection of EEE fragments for polymer modeling effectively elucidates the mechanisms governing catalyst polymerization activity, polymer molecular weight, and copolymerization performance. 3.2.2 Analyses of active species in reaction process and QSAR extraction To elucidate the QSARs of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization and identify key geometric parameters of metallocenes governing catalytic performance, we analyzed the geometric structures of all species involved in the reaction process (species 1–9, as illustrated in Fig. 1). Taking species 1 (Fig. 2 A) as an example, we systematically measured several critical geometric parameters commonly cited in the literature [32], including M–Cα bond length, M−CCp bond length, M−CFlu bond length, M–Hα bond length, Cα–Hα bond length, ∠CCp–M−CFlu angle, and ∠M–Cα–Hα angle. These parameters were subsequently determined for all nine species, with complete datasets provided in the Supporting Information (Section 4). Through correlation analysis with polymerization performance data presented in Table 1, we identified the key structural factors influencing three important aspects of catalytic performance: polymerization activity, polymer molecular weight, and 1-octene incorporation rate. 3.2.2.1 QSARs specifically refer to polymerization activity Catalytic activity serves as a crucial indicator for assessing the industrial applicability of catalysts. For metallocene catalysts, activity modulation is typically achieved through four structural parameters: bridging atom substituents, cyclopentadienyl substituents, fluorenyl substituents, and metal center atoms. This approach aligns with the catalyst design strategy outlined in Scheme 2. As demonstrated in Section 3.1, our systematic investigation revealed two primary modifications that substantially enhance polymerization activity: (1) introducing electron-donating groups to the cyclopentadienyl/fluorenyl substituents, and (2) substituting the central metal atom from Hf to Zr. These findings are consistent with previous literature report [33]. However, the influence of bridging atom substitution on catalytic properties appears highly complex, lacking a clear, consistent trend. For instance, while substituting bridging atoms from Me to Ph generally increased catalytic activity, an exception was observed between M9 and M6 (Table 1), both of which possess tert-butyl groups on their fluorenyl moieties. This anomaly suggests a highly intricate mechanistic influence of modulation of metallocene on its polymerization activity. To elucidate these structure–activity relationships, we analyzed geometric parameters across all active species in the reaction pathway. By comparing geometric parameters extracted from nine active species (Tables S6–S14) and their corresponding polymerization activities (Table 1), we identified a profound correlation between the ∠CCp–M−CFlu of species 1 (Fig. 2A) and catalytic performance. As illustrated in Fig. 3 A, polymerization activity generally increases with large ∠CCp–M−CFlu angles, except for M4, which will be discussed separately. This parameter not only explains the anomalous behavior of M9 and M6 but also provides valuable insights into the structure–activity relationship of metallocene catalysts. Furthermore, our analysis revealed that the ∠M–Cα–Hα angle in species 2 (Fig. 2B) exhibits a moderate correlation with catalytic activity, suggesting its potential role as a secondary structural determinant in the catalytic process. Fig. 3B demonstrates an inverse correlation between polymerization activity and the ∠M–Cα–Hα angle. Although this effect is less pronounced than that of the ∠CCp–M−CFlu angle, it helps explain the exceptional case of M4, thereby complementing the limitations of the ∠CCp–M−CFlu parameter. Based on these findings, we propose that the ∠CCp–M−CFlu angle (species 1) and the ∠M–Cα–Hα angle (species 2) represent two important geometric parameters governing catalyst activity. 3.2.2.2 QSARs specifically refer to polymer molecular weight The molecular weight of polymers is crucial for determining their processability and application performance [34]. Previous studies have suggested that modifying bridging atom substituents, cyclopentadienyl substituents, and fluorenyl substituents with electron-donating or bulky steric groups can enhance polymer molecular weight [33]. However, as demonstrated in Section 3.1, our findings reveal an unexpected trend: the introduction of electron-donating groups to cyclopentadienyl substituents in metallocene catalysts actually reduces the molecular weight of polymerization products, contradicting established literature [33]. Furthermore, the effects of fluorenyl substituent modification and metal center variation on polymer molecular weight remain inconclusive. For instance, while numerous studies [16,29,35] have reported increased molecular weight when substituting Zr with Hf as the metal center, our comparative analysis of M1 and M7 catalysts demonstrates the opposite trend (Table 1). To elucidate these molecular weight determinants, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of geometric parameters across nine active species of metallocene catalysts (Tables S6–S14) and their corresponding polymerization products (Table 1). Fig. 3C illustrates a prominent correlation between the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle of species 6 (Fig. 4 ) and polymer molecular weight. Specifically, the molecular weight of polymerization products displayed a unimodal distribution with respect to the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle, showing its direction dependence (the more the angle is negative or positive, the smaller the molecular weight of polymerization products) and a negative correlation with its absolute value of the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle. These findings establish the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle of species 6 as an important geometric parameter influencing polymer molecular weight. 3.2.2.3 QSARs specifically refer to 1-octene insertion rate The copolymerization capability of metallocene catalysts represents a crucial performance indicator, as the comonomer insertion rate in polymers substantially influences their properties and applications. While previous studies suggested that increasing the dihedral angle β in bridged metallocene catalysts (Scheme 1) through structural modification could enhance copolymerization performance of the metallocene catalysts in ethylene/α-olefin copolymerization [17,18,20], our findings in Section 3.1 demonstrate that this principle does not apply in the current study. Furthermore, although fluorenyl substituent modification with electron donor groups has been shown to improve copolymerization properties, the effects of cyclopentadienyl substitution and metal core atom modulation on 1-octene insertion rates remain complex and poorly understood. Through comprehensive analysis of geometric parameters across nine active species (Tables S6–S14) and their corresponding 1-octene insertion rates (Table 1), we identified the M–Cα bond length in species 9 (Fig. 5 ) as an important factor influencing copolymerization performance. As illustrated in Fig. 3D, an increased M–Cα bond length correlates with high 1-octene insertion rates. This observation aligns with the theoretical framework documented in the literature [36]. The deviation of M4 from this pattern can likely be attributed to substantial steric hindrance from the 3-position isopropyl group on the metallocene's cyclopentadienyl ring, which likely impedes the 1-octene insertion. Our analysis identified four key geometric parameters that markedly impact catalyst performance: the ∠CCp–M−CFlu angle in species 1, the ∠M–Cα–Hα angle in species 2, the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle in species 6, and the M–Cα bond length in species 9. These parameters respectively describe catalyst activity, polymerization product molecular weight, and copolymerization properties. We subsequently developed a digital catalyst model to systematically evaluate the influence of these geometric parameters on catalytic performance. 3.3 Digital catalyst model recommendation and QSAR validation As illustrated in Fig. 6 , we constructed an ANN (ANN-1) using previously reported descriptors for metallocene catalysts [25], which simultaneously predicts catalytic activity, polymerization product molecular weight, and 1-octene insertion rate. To validate the accuracy of the established QSARs, we developed ANN-2 by incorporating the above four geometric parameters as additional descriptors for catalytic performance prediction and screening (see Supporting Information Section 5 for details). Using the synthesized 11 catalysts as training samples, we designed two novel metallocene catalysts (M12 and M13, Fig. 7 ) with distinct catalytic activities through ANN-1. To investigate the importance of the four parameters, we evaluated M12 and M13 using both ANN-2 predictions and experimental measurements (synthesis and characterization data available in Supporting Information Section 1). Table 3 summarizes the catalytic polymerization properties obtained from ANN-1, ANN-2, and experimental results. The remarkable consistency between ANN-2 predictions and experimental values strongly supports the important role of these structural parameters in enhancing prediction accuracy, demonstrating their substantial influence on catalyst performance. Moreover, this approach facilitated the design of a high-performance catalyst (M12) exhibiting enhanced activity, polymer molecular weight, and copolymerization properties. We further quantified the relative influence of each descriptor in ANN-2 (Fig. 6). The analysis revealed that β (14.90 %), ∠CCp–M−CFlu (12.42 %), and ∠M–Cα–Hα (11.17 %) predominantly affect catalyst activity (Fig. 8 A), while the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle (15.79 %) primarily influences molecular weight (Fig. 8B). For copolymerization properties, β (15.83 %) and M–Cα bond length (15.55 %) emerged as the most crucial descriptors (Fig. 8C). The dominant role of β in both activity and copolymerization performance aligns with previously reported correlations [20], further validating the importance of these geometric parameters and confirming the accuracy of our QSAR models. To assess the generalizability of the ANN-2 model, we extended our investigation to include C 1-symmetric C-bridged metallocene catalysts, synthesizing two new catalysts (M14 and M15, Fig. 7) for evaluation. A detailed comparison between predicted and experimental performance data (Table 3) demonstrated excellent agreement, indicating the universal applicability of the model and its potential for high-throughput screening of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization. In conclusion, our findings validate the established QSARs through three complementary approaches: ANN–experiment integration, descriptor influence analysis, and model extension to different catalyst systems, collectively demonstrating the robustness of our catalyst digital modeling framework. 4 Conclusions This study establishes robust QSARs for bridged metallocene catalysts in ethylene/1-octene copolymerization through a synergistic integration of experimental investigations, DFT calculations, and machine learning. We demonstrate that the geometric configuration of metallocene active species during catalysis, rather than in their isolated state, is the primary determinant of catalytic performance. Specifically, the ∠CCp–M−CFlu angle angle in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2M(iBu)]+ and the ∠M–Cα–Hα angle in its ethylene π-complexes collectively govern catalytic activity, while the Cα–M−C1−C2 torsion angle in the ethylene insertion transition state ([Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC2H4(iBu)+…C2H4]‡) dictates polymer molecular weight. Furthermore, the M–Cα bond length in the transition state ([Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)+…C2H4]‡) significantly influences 1-octene insertion rates. Leveraging these QSARs, we constructed a universal digital catalyst platform with high-throughput screening capabilities, specifically tailored for the family of C 1-symmetric metallocene catalysts structurally related to the training set. This model facilitated the design of a novel catalyst exhibiting improved catalytic activity, high molecular weight polymer products, and enhanced copolymerization performance. Although the model's generalizability may be limited to untested catalyst types or unaccounted environmental variables, this work develops a machine learning framework for catalyst design under data scarcity–addressing a key challenge in the field. The established structure–activity relationships significantly enhance prediction accuracy in small–data regimes, advancing data-driven catalyst evaluation. coredata.dc:description: Metallocene catalysts are pivotal in enabling the high-temperature solution polymerization of ethylene/1-octene to produce polyolefin elastomers. Among these, bridged metallocene catalysts are particularly valuable commercially owing to their exceptional thermal stability and high catalytic activity. However, their diverse and complex structural characteristics pose major challenges in the precise and controllable design and synthesis of catalysts that simultaneously exhibit high activity, superior copolymerization performance, and the ability to produce high-molecular-weight polymers. Herein, the quantitative structure–activity relationships (QSARs) of C 1-symmetric bridged metallocene catalysts for ethylene/1-octene copolymerization were investigated through a combined experimental and density functional theory approach. In contrast to most studies that focus solely on the catalyst structure, our findings emphasize the importance of analyzing catalyst performance based on the transition state species formed during the reaction. Specifically, the ∠CCp–M−CFlu and the ∠M–Cα–Hα of ethylene π-complexes in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2M(iBu)]+ were identified as important influencing factor of catalytic activity. Additionally, the M–Cα bond length in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC4H8(iBu)+…C2H4] ‡ was found to influence copolymerization performance, while the Cα–M−C1−C2 twist angle in [Cp(R1)Ind(R2)2Si(R)2MC2H4(iBu)+…C2H4]‡ directly affected the molecular weight of the polymerization product. These QSARs were further validated through machine learning and experimental verification. Based on these insights, a novel high-performance catalyst was designed and synthesized. Finally, a universally applicable digital catalyst model with high-throughput screening capabilities was developed, leveraging the obtained QSARs.
